name: Capsized
description: Capsized is a fast paced 2D platformer focused on intense action and exploration. As a intrepid space traveler, your ship has crash landed on a mysterious alien planet. You must navigate through the perilous environment and fight off blood-thirsty creatures to save your crewmates and escape with your lives!
minimum_requirements: OS: XP/Vista/Windows 7 Processor: Dual-core processor (Intel Dual Core 2.0 GHz or AMD Athlon X2 5200+ 2.6 GHz) Memory: 1.5 GB RAM Hard Disk Space: 1.0 GB free space Video Card: DirectX 9.0c compatible Sound: DirectX 9.0c compatible sound cards

reviews.review_text: Well, what a wonderful game. Honestly, got is a part of indie humble bundle. Thought I'd try it out because was quite bored. And it turned out to be my favourite game of the year as of now.  AS a 2D platformer it is quite demanding on your system - however nothing an average system can't manage (integrated graphics cards tend to have little support and in that regard run the game quite sluggishly. if you've got a separate gpu then it's gonna run smoothly). Nonetheless personally I think it's a beautiful game, even stunning. Mechanics are great - very enjoyable fighting, nice variety of weapons available and they all feel different too (a bit too 'soft' and 'smooth' for heavy guns like a rocket louncher or so, but it's futuristic plasma rounds that you're firing so I think it reflects on that well). Many different kinds of opponents that you will have to figure out how to kill, so it's not too much of a straight 'shoot em up' platformer.  Where this game really excels is its soundtrack. The atmosphere it creates is simply... breathtaking. As a part of bundle I received it separately as mp3, and am listening to in on a regular basis - it's that good. You will quickly notice that this game is not lengthy. Still it leaves plenty of room for prolongued gameplay, especially if you like picking up achievements and accomplishing everything to perfection.  To round up, as mentioned I was so blown away by this game - gameplay, soundtrack and (forgot to mention) story wise. Definetely pick it up if you're a platformer fan (imho it doesn't redefine the genre in any way - however it does show that it's still got that kick), and, well, even if you're not. I guarantee you will not be let down.

Absolutely hated the game. Which is a shame, because I loved the atmosphere/graphics and sound. Enemies are not 'hard' in the traditional sense, just super frustrating. Some puzzles turn unsolvable if you made some mistake during the sometimes lengthy levels (level 11 I'm looking at you). Capsized is a game with good ideas, but numerous design issues.  The game features a cosmonaut on a green planet fighting green aliens against a green backdrop and behind green vines. Yes, it is as cluttered as it sounds. The main menu, which consists of white text on a white background (which thankfully scrolls to other colours so you can actually read the text) gives you a good idea of what the rest of the game is going to be like. Eventually, you get used to it, but the developers do not seem to understand that 'good graphics' doesn't just mean nice looking textures. You have to use contrast as well. Draw the players attention to important things, don't hide it in a field of clutter.  The vsync option in the game also does nothing (at least on the Linux version, anyways), and has no frame limiting. In other words, no matter how slow or how fast your computer is, you will have loads of screen tearing. I switched to windowed mode since I have my window manager (Compiz) set to vsync windowed programs whether they like it or not. I then discovered that the game doesn't try to keep your mouse in the window, so be prepared to accidentally click outside of the game a lot.  Moving on to actual gameplay, the idea of using a grappling 'hook' to swing around a low gravity environment and toss enemies around sounds great, but it behaves very strangely mechanically. Shooting a grappling hook horizontally into a wall somehow manages to let you move upwards? I also found the ability to stick to walls was preventing me from moving where I wanted to go instead of helping me.  The are some other minor issues that could have easily been fixed had more rigorous testing been done. For example, many of your weapons cause splash damage that does very high damage to you if you're too close to where it hits. There are also rapid fire weapons that fire while you hold down the mouse button. When you expend all the ammuniton in one weapon, it automatically switches you to another weapon, firing it if the mouse is currently down. See the problem?  Oh, and the game freezes when you try to exit it, so there's that too.
DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine

Capsized demands accuracy, something its clumsy controls make nearly impossible. It is a shame how such a beautifully crafted game world can be so utterly destroyed by a developer's failure to heed to the mere fundamentals of game creation. Presentation alone is not enough to save this mediocre platformer. 5.6/10.

The game offers a wide variety of weapons mixed with the movement tactics of the hook and jet pack! The hook is the grappling hook from metroid but works on almost any surface in the game and allows the player to reach very high places along with evading enimies. I suggest giving this game a try and see for yourself. OH and the soundtrack is very good aswell!   Thanks for reading.

This game has it all. It looks great, the music sounds great and sets the tone well and the gameplay is smooth as silk. Great platforming, very interactive physics and fun combat come together in a crazy fun package that is well worth the price. The campaign may be short but the game is highly replayable and really promotes score chasing with some fun unlockable modes. Grab the demo and play through a level or two multiple times to see how this game can provide hours and hours of entertainment. Add on the Bonus Modes and you have some great staying power. And enough can't be said about the artwork. Hand drawn graphics create a great atmosphere, with fun designs for enemies and a main character that will have you living out your astronaut dreams. With some crazy firepower, a fantastic grapple/ram and JETPACKS.

You've been shipwrecked on some planet and you need to save your mates and get home.  You have a bunch of weapons and a tractor beam of sorts to push and pull stuff. Oh, and it can be used for climbing...but so can your jetpack. Redundant, I know.  There's no story aside from some pictures to start levels. Levels all look basically the same.  All the enemies seem to be animal-like in their nature, so why there are weapons laying everywhere I don't understand. They're kind of dumb too. Every one has specific patterns and once you figure them out you'll shoot from a distance to avoid attacks. Some enemies at the end get a bit stupid to counter this tactic. For example, one enemy creates its own gravity well to pull everything in, including your photon blasts, and somehow the live ammo and shots don't damage it, but get shot back to you after a time.  This game gets great reviews on Steam, but it didn't blow my skirt up. It's also short. I beat it in a couple of hours. Fun enough for a night, but at about level 8 of 12 I was ready for the game to be done.

Fantastic Game!  I originally got this in the Humble Bundle 8, but haven't given it a shot until now. The story is simple and straight forward, assigning a different task to each mission with all having the ultimate goal of escaping the strange alien planet you find yourself on. The gameplay itself is fun and offers a variey of ways of movement between wall jumping, hook shotting and jetpacking when you have the fuel. There are a varity of weapons to choose from each having their own unique way of attacking. The enemies also vary from simple hostile primitive creatures to the more advanced aliens which range from grunts with guns to tough guardians with magical abilities. The environment is eerie and intrigues a sense of curiosity and exploration. Probably my favorite part about the game though, is the soundtrack. It fits incredibly well with the lost spacey feel of the game and will have you googling for the artist before the game is through. All in all, this game really impressed me and has been one of the most delightful games I have played in the past year. If any of this sounds good to you, don't hesitate to treat yourself to a copy!

Don't make the mistake I did and think that Capsized is some kind of exploration-heavy metroidvania thing. The mentions of exploring and using tools to navigate might suggest that, but it's a very different beast. What you're getting is a floaty sci-fi platformer with a lot of shooting, a lot of physics puzzles, and a lot of frustration. And it might just be short enough to finish before you get fed up with it.  Capsized sees you stranded on an alien world that wastes no time trying to waste you. The natives are restless and the fauna is deadly, and most levels are going to be spent depopulating the area so you can accomplish your goal. Instead of big, sprawling areas, Capsized takes place in fairly compact levels, each one starting you from scratch and tasking you to search high and low for weapons, jetpack fuel, extra lives, and other power-ups. I must emphasize, nothing is carried over between campaign missions, leaving each of the 12 levels feeling a bit thin.  There's not a lot to do besides kill things, collect power-ups if you're having trouble killing things, and finish the level. Sometimes you need to reach a certain point, sometimes you need to collect doodads, and sometimes you really do just have to kill a bunch of stuff. Navigating the levels to do that might prove difficult, as your spaceman is very floaty and easy to send flying. He can wall jump almost effortlessly, grapple things with a grappling beam, and jetpack around, all with mounting momentum that can easily get unmanageable.  You'll be shoving and grappling plenty of blocks, too, because Capsized loves physics puzzles. It feels odd calling them physics puzzles, though, because it's usually just a tunnel blocked with junk or a pressure plate that needs to be held down. Finishing said 'puzzles' is another source of frustration, since the stones and boxes use the same physics as you and can easily drift away or rocket off the screen. The worst is when you're expected to use a block as a shield against the game's incredibly lethal traps, watching your spaceman get perforated as the block he's holding wobbles around lazily.  Dying is very much the low part of the game, and it comes more and more frequently the further in you get. Enemies and especially traps can do tons of damage, and as they become more dense in the later levels it gets that much harder to avoid big chunks of hurt. When you die you either respawn at the last 1-up you collected OR the start of the level, which is infuriating in the more maze-like levels. Several of your best guns also do splash damage to you, and there are plenty of little critters that love to run up and attach to your face to catch mortars for you.  The art is fantastically detailed, but becomes a bit too busy for a game like this. Sound design is nice and somber but the effects in battle, both audio and visual, are sorely lacking. There's so little impact to weapons you'll never really know how much damage is being done until your enemy (or you) is dead. A few co-op and arcade modes round out the game but the fact is that you're getting a 12-mission campaign that can be beaten in two hours, provided it doesn't make you rage. And whether it be the giant boulder that just will not get out of your way, or the jetpack sniper that runs you out of lives, something will most likely make you jump ship early.

If there were two words I'd describe this game with, it would be 'competent' and 'anemic'. It has that lovely FPS shooter feel to it, and the best parts of the game are jetpacking over the aliens and raining laser death down on their stupid flightless heads! However, that's not enough to save it for me. There are a bunch of little niggling flaws, including uninspired controlling, uninspired mapping and even more uninspired secret finding (they are called secrets for a reason, guys, not 'mementos with hidden pathways!'). BLOODY SCREEN appears when your character is about to die, and instead of pairing it with regenerating health, the screen stays there until you find a health kit, making navigation a bit of a ♥♥♥♥ing pain. All that, and at two-three hours, the game still feels like it's trying to pad itself out. So it's got that Quake 1 action feel but it's about as interesting as Quake 2. Try the demo first.

I do recommend this game, but it is with a major caveat... the controls are terrible. It’s just bad wrong. It is playable, but I gave up after a while because the mouse/kb wasn't cutting it for me. You'd thing, 'Oh, but look, it supports controllers.' but so did I. It's actually worse. You might think I am just being a negative reviewer for the sake of irritation on my part, but I really wanted to love this game. In a way I do... I love the graphics, music, animations, weapons, aliens, and just about EVERYTHING (aside from the slightly lightweight campaign). Unfortunately, unless the developer updates to better enable controllers to work with this game, it’s going to remain a 'don't buy' recommendation from me. It's a sad thing too, because I really watched this one come to life from its early stages of kick starter. It’s that one really important missing piece keeping this game from truly being a gem of the indie trend.

The game looks great, though, and has decent weapon variety. There seems to be little difference from one level to the next.

7/10  A really fun indie side scroller that has elements of platforming and physics puzzling with a dash of killing aliens. The controls take a little to get used to with keyboard and mouse, especially the rapid fire nature of the jumping if left pressed down for a second. All in all though, a very cool game with a little bit of something for everyone.

A pretty good side scrolling shooting game (think old school Metroid or Castlevania) with a great ambient soundtrack and hand drawn sprites/background. The story, although simple, is enough to keep one playing through the game and more enemies are added to in keep things interesting. My only gripe about the game like many other reviews is the difficulty curve gets incredibly difficult half way through the game. Going from losing no lives in the first couple of maps to losing over half of my lives on a single map can be quite frustrating. What more, I feel that some of the puzzle traps do not translate well to the controls of the game, forcing the player to merely minimize damage as they run through certain areas of the game. Despite all the issues I would definitely recommend picking the game up in a bundle or while on sale. I beat the game in a couple of hours, so keep that in mind when purchasing.  7.5/10.0

Capsized is a great game for it's price. Lots of weapons and enemies, nice visuals, a solid long story with replayability for collectables and even splitscreen mode!

Capsized is not without its problems. It's floaty controls and uninvited physics-puzzle mechanics can sometimes make the platformer unnecessarily frustrating. When it shines though, it shines. Shootouts often become intense and frenetic as you fling yourself around the lush alien landscape trying to avoid flying enemies and projectiles. The artwork and sound alone are enough to make you want to come back.

A lovely game. It reminded me a bit of 'Alien Breed' mixed with 'Flashback' on the Amiga (which is a good thing!). The music compliments the atmosphere of the game perfectly, as does the artwork. Love it. Excellent. A+
Hella fun Metroidvania game. Difficulty scales well and the weapons are fun and intuitive to learn with a surprising amount of tactical complexity. Buy it.
Capsized is a really, really good platformer. Lots of great weapons and powerups. Good times: highly recommended. WARNING: Game is seriously hard! Ouch!

Initial gameplay is very immersive: the environment is beautiful and enjoyable to look at; enemies and weapons are diversified; the game boasts brave new platformer mechanics and a smoothe physics engine. The atmosphere and hidden items are reminiscent of Metrtroid, and succeed in adding to each level's replay value.  Although the first few levels are fun, the difficulty curve skyrockets unexpectedly at approximately the fourth level. I'm not sure if this was intentional, but it does so regardless of the difficulty setting chosen. The last thing I was expecting was for an indie game to turn hardcore midway through, hence I would only recommend this game to someone looking for an extremely challenging platformer.   6.5/10  Play the demo first.
